content.body: by curiosity I tried to render the same origin algorithm http://www.la-grange.net/2010/01/22/same-origin-algorithm.png
might be wrong
karlcow: Yeah, it's wrong.  The opaque-identifier portion should completely separate from the same-components section.  If they're opaque, they don't *have* components.
TabAtkins: ah. I'll modify. It is not clear in the prose of the spec I have the feeling.
likes to visualize to understand
If you translate it from prose directly to if/then code in your favorite programming language, it becomes very clear.  ^_^
(python)
but my favorite languages are 1. fr:poetry 2. graphic_representation
TabAtkins: thanks
huh, brief power black out in mountain view
i wonder what that was about
my bet: the PROJECT has escaped ;)
cue x-files melody
nobody twittered about it that i can see, so... maybe just the complex i'm in
i should get a UPS
that power outage ruined by 250+ day uptime
(on the box linux box routing all my network traffic, which i installed about 250 days ago)
I wonder if development of the 'uptime' program was secretly supported by the people who make UPS devices
hah
are UPSes any good these days? 15 years ago they could barely do 7 minutes for your typical load
wow, apparently not
3 minutes?!
5 minutes?!
$378 for less than 7 minutes at barely 1kW?
my _iPod_ can last a whole day, and it fits in my pocket
my g1 lasts a whole hour, and it fits in my - OH WAIT :D
surely something that can be put under a desk, that doesn't need to handle continuous drain-charge cycles, and that is plugged into the mains most of the day, can do better
i wonder how much petrol would be needed for a generator to support a 1kW load for an hour
surely we have rechargeable materials with more efficient power densities than petrol by now
grumbles at hardware people :-P
as if
i was buying a printer recently and as far as i could tell, they essentially haven't improved in 10 years
and now i find UPSes haven't improved in like 15 years
i know chips improve, and laptops improve, and software sure has improved, and network connectivity has improved
so wtf are the printer and UPS people doing?!
working on their uranium-powered printers in their secret lair ? ;)
i hope so
when they finally release something new, it had better be effing AWESOME.
like bre-pettis-AWESOME :D
thats it. printer people worked on adding more dimensions to their plotters !

i expect hte next gen printers to be able to print onto a whole ream of paper at once without moving any of the sheets, so that you just stick a ream in, and then you pick it up three seconds later and the whole ream is fully printed
DOUBLE-SIDED.
and the next gen UPS had better just be a cable you can replace your current cable with
nono, they print the paper as well
which lasts 72 hours on one charge, charges in 5 seconds, and can support 10MW loads.
looks like you're going for an Uranium Power Supply there â€¦
wow, the comments from some of the CSSWG memebers regarding selectors api on public-webapps/www-style seem surprisingly confused about how it works.
also about the use cases that are being addressed, but that's slightly more understandable if they haven't actively followed its development
I suppose I should clearly document all of those somewhere, outside of the mailing list discussion, for easy reference.
I'll put it on the whatwg wiki
Hixie, build your own UPS out of an array of car batteries. They should last quite a while, if you have enough.
You could just use a laptop
http://www.dansdata.com/upsupgrade.htm or http://www.dansdata.com/diyups.htm
Philip`: the laptops didn't die, but it turns out they're useless without the wireless router and the cable modem
Philip`: and the mac mini stops being entertaining when it, its media disk, its speakers, and its screen all go off at once
Hixie, is a mac mini particularly entertaining for some reason when it's on?
perhaps if you use it as a media centre
it's my tv replacement
ok
and music player
and all around entertainment system
You could use laptops with one laptop acting as a wireless router, connected to the internet via the mobile phone network
Also, you could entertain yourself by reading a book
So there's really no reason to worry about power cuts at all
(Well, for the book you might need some candles too)
where can I find the documentation for html5lib?
Huvet: import html5lib; help(html5lib)
(from Python interpreter)
seems to be about the only documentation, given that the wiki seems to have lost its pages
ok, thanks
Philip`: what are these "candles" you speak of
isn't that a unit of brightness
candles are a fire hazard, especially because you need a few hundred of them to replicate the amount of light obtained from a decent 100W incandescent bulb (or equivalent).
It's possible to see quite adequately without needing the equivalent of a 100W incandescent bulb
isn't suggesting using them as an identical replacement for current electrical lighting systems
Huvet: There is some documentation somewhere but it got lost at some point
http://html5lib.googlecode.com/svn/wiki/UserDocumentation.wiki
(it may not be entirely up to date)
ah, thanks
jgraham: Do you know why that doesn't show up on the web page?
(http://code.google.com/p/html5lib/w/list links to UserDocumentation but says page not found)
Maybe it's a SVN vs Hg thing?
Philip`, trying to read in rooms that have less light than that from a 100W bulb, or better yet, long fluroescent tube lighting, can get quite tiring for my eyes.
Well, you could use the light to illuminate the book and not the entire room
has a 20W desk lamp that's easily more than adequate
I know what everyone finds comfortable is different, but I can't work with desk lamps. They give an uncomfortable bright spot while the rest of the room is comparitively dark.
Philip`: I guess it must be but I think it worked for a while after we switched (but I could be wrong about that)
(however I blame Google anyway)
Lachy: You need smaller rooms
Is JF saying that if we can't be sure about author intent, we should abandon all attempts at doing anything useful?
Dashiva: It's strange, but that's the vibe I get too.
I'm guessing it's a particular manifestation of "perfect is the enemy of good".
Dashiva: I don't think so.
I can't imagine he would, but I'm having trouble reading it any other way
I think he's just saying the spec should not imply feasibility of "non-existent techniques".
and taking the phrase "image analysis heuristics" to imply technology that can determine author intent.
I think that's a stretch, but meh.
Yes, that
is reasonable, until someone tells you that's not what it means :)
Dashiva: Yeah, but even from that point, you can still make assertions that the spec's language implies something different that what is meant (or is ambiguous).
Dashiva: hence his citing of a dictionary definition of heuristics, I guess.
Protip: As soon as you're citing dictionary definitions, you've lost the argument.
Not really sure that's true.
Not when you're discussing what does a blob of text imply, anyhow.
That is, there's a difference between an argument about essences and an argument about phrasing.
I find that even in that sort of dicussion, whipping out a dictionary means the argument is officially over and you're on the losing side.
It's like godwining.
A /better/ argument, I find is to point to examples of other readers reading it that way.
But - that's more expensive.
microdata toy for all the children: http://foolip.org/microdatajs/demo/live.html
fun!
That provert is new to me
*proverb
foolip: On the vcard and ical tabs, you mean "itemtype"

Hixie: I sent a big list of sites that use cut/copy/paste events in email
Hixie: if you would like help figuring out exactly how they use those events, I can try to gather more data, but I think they all have obfuscated JavaScript so it's hard for me to tell directly
